text: Hello! Do you want to learn more about Tic-Tac-Toe game?

question.text:
Tic-Tac-Toe is an ancient game that dates back to the Roman Empire. 
The Romans played a game called "Terni Lapilli" which had similar rules but was played on a different grid. 
The game was also played in ancient Egypt and China, making it one of the oldest known games.

Tic-Tac-Toe is a mathematically solvable game. 
This means that with optimal play from both players, the game will always end in a draw. 
There are 765 unique positions and 26,830 possible games that can be played in Tic-Tac-Toe. 
Knowing the perfect strategy ensures that you can never lose the game, 
although it doesn't guarantee a win if your opponent also plays perfectly.

Tic-Tac-Toe is often used in the field of computer science to teach algorithms and artificial intelligence (AI). 
Due to its simplicity, it's a great way to introduce concepts such as game theory, decision trees, and the minimax algorithm. 
Early AI programs, like the one created by Arthur Samuel in the 1950s, 
used Tic-Tac-Toe to demonstrate machine learning and decision-making processes.

Classic Tic-Tac-Toe: 
This is the standard version of the game played on a 3x3 grid. 
Two players take turns marking an empty cell with their symbol (X or O). 
The goal is to be the first to get three of your marks in a row, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. 

If all cells are filled without either player achieving this, the game ends in a draw.

5 in a Line (Gomoku): 
Also known as Five in a Row, this game is played on a larger grid, typically 15x15 or 19x19. 

Players take turns placing their marks on the board with the objective of getting five in a row, 
horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. Unlike classic Tic-Tac-Toe, 
which often ends in a draw with optimal play, 
Gomoku requires deeper strategic thinking and planning due to the larger grid 
and the increased number of marks needed to win.

Connect Four (4 in a Height): 
This game is played on a vertical grid, usually 7 columns wide and 6 rows high. 
Players take turns dropping their colored discs into one of the columns, with the discs falling 
to the lowest available position within the column. 
The goal is to be the first to connect four of your discs in a row, either horizontally, 
vertically, or diagonally. 

Connect Four adds a gravity element to the gameplay, making it a unique challenge compared to traditional Tic-Tac-Toe.
